content:
Hi David, thanks for the response. Unfortunately it doesn't work. I had those options checked and just redid it and then sent myself a message from a different email browser.

It looks like that should do the job but it doesn't make any change to the icon when new mail comes in. Again the concept is wanting to know that a new message has come in just by glancing at it rather than opening it fruitlessly multiple times throughout the day. Not sure if this is something in my system but it tells me that this is the most up-to-date version of TB so not sure what the problem might be. Thanks again for the response
creator: fhoran1

content: In settings>general you have the option to show the number of unread messages on the task bar. You can also specify that a sound be played.
creator: davidsk

content: Is LibreOffice a 32 or 64 bit app? If it's 32-bit, TB must also be 32-bit to send documents from LO to TB.
creator: sfhowes

content: Would you please post a screenshot of the composition&addressing pane of the account? This is something I haven't seen before. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: I am not sure exactly what you are seeing, but you might click settings>general and untick the box for the Thunderbird startup page.
creator: davidsk

content: Ochrana uložených hesel v Thunderbirdu pomocí hlavního hesla Upozornění: Tato akce odstraní všechna vaše uložená uživatelská jména a hesla.
creator: poljos-moz

content: Check to see what folders they are in. Then, rightclick on account in left pane and click 'subscribe' to the folders.
creator: davidsk

content: In the message list pane, look for the top line that shows 'subject, from, date, etc...' Click 'date' to change the order of appearance of messages.
creator: davidsk

content: Hello David, I'll check it out later, but your answer seems to go in the right direction. Thank you very, very much
creator: vvld-ml-2020

content: In windows file explorer, you should see a folder named Data as a subfolder of the portable version. In that folder is the profile folder, possibly named Thunderbird. In that folder, look for the Mail folder for POP accounts and the Imapmail folder for IMAP accounts. I have seen multiple approaches to portable versions, but I think this info will get you there.
creator: davidsk
